post_text: To enhance virtual learning, elementary students in grades K-5 are receiving a packet of materials for reading and math. They include rulers, composition notebooks primary journals, letter sound charts, multiplication tables, grid paper, and so much more! Each elementary school has or will soon be distributing the packets.

TIME IS RUNNING OUT! The Roanoke Career and Technical Education Foundation is holding its annual Silent Auction online. You have until Sunday (9/20) to place your bid! Here is the link to participate:

https://event.auctria.com/a8b257cf-be86-42c9-82db-dc53500c9a31/

Auction items include a Nintendo Switch, gift cards, jewelry, fire pits, and much more! Proceeds from the Silent Auction will provide scholarships to CTE students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools. THANK YOU for your support.

post_text: It's Constitution Day! The U.S. Constitution was adopted on this day in 1787. Whether in-person or virtually, students are still learning about this momentous occasion. In Ms. Holbrook's third grade class, students will write their own Constitution for Virginia Heights Elementary. Upon completion, the teacher will display their work on the wall at school.

post_text: This year's theme is "We Will Rise." Ms. Turner's idea is a great example. She leads the Piano Lab at William Fleming High School. It's hard to teach piano virtually. You can't exactly move a grand piano into each student's home. At her suggestion, the District purchased Roll-Up Pianos. They arrived this week and will soon be available for students to use at home. THANK YOU Ms. Turner for thinking outside the box.

post_text: It's been a good start to the school year at Forest Park Academy. FPA welcomed 82 students back last week for in-person instruction. Staff and students are screened each morning. They must wear masks at all times and practice social distancing. Forest Park Academy is a specialized high school that helps students overcome challenges and graduate. Since its inception, FPA has exceeded 1,300 graduates. Congratulations Dr. Anderson, Ms. Garst, and the entire staff at Forest Park Academy.

Since its inception, FPA has exceeded 1,300 graduates. Congratulations Dr. Anderson, Ms. Garst, and the entire staff at Forest Park Academy.

post_text:
Roanoke City Public Schools has already identified 264 students as homeless so far this school year. In the past week, the District secured hotels for four families that needed emergency housing. This was made possible thanks to the efforts of our Help the Homeless Fund. Due to the pandemic, your help is needed now more than ever. Please consider donating money or items to help our homeless students. Here is a link with more information:

https://www.rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=2014934

THANK YOU for your support.

post_text:
MEAL DISTRIBUTION UPDATE: The USDA no longer requires enrollment to receive meals for students. Anyone 18 and under can get a free meal from Roanoke City Public Schools. Under USDA guidelines, parents/guardians will need to provide names if their children are not present.

To simplify the process, beginning Tuesday, September 22, meal pick-up and delivery will take place Tuesdays and Thursdays. Families may pick-up meals on Tuesdays and Thursdays for their children by ONE of the following options:

Pick-Up Onsite Option:

Days:Tuesday and Thursdays
Time: 11:30 AM-12:30 PM
Sites: Fallon Park, Round Hill, Patrick Henry, and William Fleming
Days:Tuesdays and Thursdays
Time: 5:00 PM -6:30 PM
Sites: Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools
Pick-Up at Bus Stop:

Days: Tuesdays and Thursdays
Time: 10:30 AM-1 PM

Here's a link with bus route information: https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/meal_distribution_information

post_text:
PLEASE SHARE: The Roanoke Career and Technical Education (ROTEC) Foundation is hosting its Silent Auction online. You may remember the annual ROTEC Extravaganza was canceled due to the pandemic. All money raised will provide scholarships to CTE students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools. Here is the link to bid:

charityauction.bid/rotec

The auction is open from now until September 20! Items include handmade firepits, gift cards, a Nintendo Switch, and much more! Winners can pick up their items at ROTEC (Patrick Henry campus) after the auction closes. If you have questions, please email Kathy Duncan at kduncan@rcps.info

post_text: PLEASE READ: It has come to our attention that a spam email has been sent to a number of student email accounts. The subject line is Per Time Job. Please make sure your student DOES NOT reply or even open the email. In fact, they should delete it immediately. If your student replied to the email, please call 853-1000. Remember, Roanoke City Public Schools will NEVER ask you or your student personal information through email. Thank you for your help with this matter.
text: PLEASE READ: It has come to our attention that a spam email has been sent to a number of student email accounts. The subject line is Per Time Job. Please make sure your student DOES NOT reply or even open the email. In fact, they should delete it immediately. If your student replied to the email, please call 853-1000. Remember, Roanoke City Public Schools will NEVER ask you or your student personal information through email. Thank you for your help with this matter.

post_text:
Eleanor and her younger sister had a blast with the make-your-own pizza kits provided by SodexoMAGIC.

We want to share some great news! The USDA no longer requires enrollment to receive meals for students. Anyone 18 and under can get a free meal from Roanoke City Public Schools. Due to USDA guidelines, parents/guardians will have to provide the names if their children are not present.

Roanoke City Public Schools will soon change the process for pick-up/delivery. We believe these changes will make it easier on everyone. They are scheduled to be implemented the week of September 22. Once finalized, we will provide additional details.

For a list of pick-up sites and bus routes, check out this website:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/meal_distribution_information

post_text: John Otey received a warm Lincoln Terrace welcome! This morning, the faculty gathered in the courtyard to meet the new principal. They were joined by Superintendent Verletta White, K-5 Executive Director Greg Johnston, Fleming Principal Archie Freeman, and Ruth Claytor. Mr. Otey has served as an assistant principal in Roanoke City since 2018. He previously was a teacher in Bedford County and athletic director at William Fleming High School. Congratulations!

post_text: WATCH THIS: You probably haven't seen a ball drop quite like this! Science teachers gathered at Central Office to drop 1,750 superballs down a stairway. Why? It's an activity for middle school students in Physical Science. They are about to study Newton's Law of Motion. Students will receive a take home lab packet with a superball and a paper meter stick to collect data at home and share it in their Canvas Science Class. Using the DoubleTake app, you can see the ball drop from two different angles. Enjoy!
text: WATCH THIS: You probably haven't seen a ball drop quite like this! Science teachers gathered at Central Office to drop 1,750 superballs down a stairway. Why? It's an activity for middle school students in Physical Science. They are about to study Newton's Law of Motion. Students will receive a take home lab packet with a superball and a paper meter stick to collect data at home and share it in their Canvas Science Class. Using the DoubleTake app, you can see the ball drop from two different angles. Enjoy!

post_text: Our students are making amazing art from home! Ms. McCauley asked her students from Garden City and Morningside Elementary Schools to look at a book called "Anywhere Artist" by Nikki Slade Robinson. It's about a little girl who makes art wherever she is with whatever she can find - she doesn't need real art supplies. Students then walked around their neighborhood and found objects to create their own work of art. Thanks McCauley for sharing these pictures. Great job students.

post_text:
A shout out to Candy, Laura, and Dana from Data and Analysis for stuffing 2,000 bags full of school supplies for today's Back-to-School Extravaganza. If your child needs school supplies and is enrolled in Roanoke City Public Schools, please come to William Fleming High School today (8/30) from 3 to 5 p.m. This remains a drive-thru event and we ask everyone to stay in their vehicle.

Transportation is available from the following locations: Blue Stone Park, Hunt Manor, Indian Rock Village, Jamestown Place, Landsdowne Park, Melorse Towers, Pilot Street (Country Cookin). Buses leave promptly at 1:45 p.m. We ask that you wear a face covering.

Unfortunately, immunizations cannot be provided at this event. However, the Roanoke City Health Department will host a Drive-Thru Immunization Clinic Monday (8/31) from 9 a.m. to 11:00, as well as 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. Please bring your child's immunization card and insurance (if applicable). The Health Department is located at 1502 Williamson Road, NE.

FINAL REMINDER: Today (8/28) at 5 p.m. is the deadline to complete the meal enrollment form to receive meals starting Monday, August 31. All students enrolled in Roanoke City Public Schools may receive 5 breakfast meals and 5 lunch meals weekly at no cost. We will offer grab and go sites Monday and Wednesdays and delivery by bus Tuesday and Thursdays. The federal government requires the forms. Here is a link to complete the form online:

https://www.myschoolbucks.com/ver2/getmain.action

Paper copies are also available at each school. Estimated delivery times will be posted are on our website by this afternoon. Here is a link for bus routes, list of grab and go sites, and other details:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/meal_distribution_information

This year's welcome back to teachers was videotaped at William Fleming High School. We wish Convocation could have been in person! Mayor Lea and School Board Chairperson Lutheria Smith bring greetings from the Roanoke City Council and School Board, respectively, and Superintendent White lays out her vision for the school year. We also honored Myra Wasson of Fallon Park Elementary, the 2020 Teacher of the Year.

For closed captioning, please see: https://youtu.be/12NJ10ECLI0

post_text: #RoanokeRocks You may have noticed this colorful art display on the Roanoke River Greenway below the Memorial Avenue Bridge. Did you know a group from Patrick Henry High School is helping to create this masterpiece? The Arches showcases the classic architectural styles of Roanoke. post_text:
Monday, August 31 is quickly approaching! With the first student day just around the corner, Roanoke City Public Schools wants to share attendance expectations for virtual learning (Canvas):

All students who either participate during live instruction or complete assignments and/or assessments will be considered present

Students must log onto Canvas and complete assignments each school day

At 5:00 p.m. each day, a robo call will be sent for those students who did not attend and participate during synchronous (live) instruction and have not completed assignments/assessments for the day

Students will have until the next morning to log into Canvas and complete assignments. This will accommodate working parents who need to help their student with virtual learning

post_text:
UPDATE ON MEAL DISTRIBUTION: Parents/guardians now have until Friday (8/28) to complete the meal enrollment forms. In order to receive meals for your children beginning August 31, YOU MUST COMPLETE THIS FORM. This is a federal requirement. All students enrolled in Roanoke City Public Schools may receive 5 breakfast meals and 5 lunch meals weekly at no cost. We will offer grab and go sites Monday and Wednesdays and delivery by bus Tuesday and Thursdays. Here is a link to complete the form online:

https://www.myschoolbucks.com/ver2/getmain.action

If you can't complete the form online, please call 853-2863. Additionally, Roanoke City Public Schools has added evening hours for guardians to pick up student meals. It will take place Mondays and Wednesday from 5:00 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. at Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools.

post_text:
#RoanokeRocks THANK YOU to our friends from Hill Street Baptist Church for helping us sort and bag school supplies for our students. We appreciate their on-going support.

REMINDER: If your child needs school supplies, our Back to School Extravaganza will take place this Saturday (8/29) at William Fleming High School from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. It will be a Drive-Thru event. Everyone is asked to remain in their vehicles unless your child needs immunizations. The Health Department will provide Immunizations from 9 a.m. to noon only. Please bring your insurance card and your child's immunization record.

Roanoke City Public Schools will provide transportation at 8:45 a.m. from the following locations: Blue Stone Park, Hunt Manor, Indian Rock Village, Jamestown Place, Landsdowne Park, Melorse Towers, Pilot Street (Country Cookin).

The bus leaves promptly at 8:45 a.m. Please wear face coverings on the bus. Durham will provide at least two buses at each location to assist with social distancing.

The United Way has created a FAQ section to answer some of the commonly asked questions about childcare options for Roanoke City Public Schools. Here is the link:

http://smart2start.org/smart2start-faq-roanoke-city/

The United Way has received more than 400 applications already. Staff is working quickly to process the applications. Please be patient. Funds are available to assist with childcare costs for our students who are learning virtually. Funding, up to $21 a day per student, is available and will be paid directly to participating daycare providers. Here is a link to apply:

http://smart2start.org/

post_text:
REMINDER: With the City of Roanoke’s help, funds are available to assist with childcare costs since most students will begin the school year virtually for the first nine weeks. Funding, up to $21 a day per student, is available and will be paid directly to participating daycare providers. In addition to the federal funding that is available, the United Way's navigator team will also assist parents with DSS subsidies, to minimize the out-of-pocket costs even further.

They include YMCA of Virginia's Blue Ridge, Boys and Girls Club of Southwest Virginia, Goodwill, Imagine Me Mentor, , West End Center, Science Museum of Western Virginia, Toadally Kidz, Great Beginnings Academy, Cultural Arts for Excellence

Here is a link to apply: http://smart2start.org/

The United Way has created a FAQ section for Roanoke City. Here is the link:

http://smart2start.org/smart2start-faq-roanoke-city/

THANK YOU SodexoMAGIC employees for all your hard work this summer distributing meals to students. Just a reminder, beginning August 31st, Roanoke City Schools will participate in the USDA National School Lunch and Breakfast program. PLEASE NOTE: In order to receive meals, the federal government now requires each household to compete a meal enrollment form. Please login onto MySchoolBucks to complete the form. Here is a link:

https://www.myschoolbucks.com/ver2/getmain.action

Paper copies are also available at each school. If you need assistance with the form, please call 853-2863. All students enrolled in Roanoke City Public Schools may receive 5 breakfast meals and 5 lunch meals weekly at no cost. We will offer grab and go sites Monday and Wednesdays and delivery by bus Tuesday and Thursdays. Here is a link with a list of sites and other details:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/meal_distribution_information

From 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., students enrolled in Roanoke City Public Schools can receive a bag of school supplies. You only have to leave your vehicle if you need Immunizations. The bus leaves promptly at 8:45 a.m. Please wear face coverings on the bus. Durham will provide at least two buses at each location to assist with social distancing.

We are here to help! Ellen Craddock, director of Food Services, walks us through the MySchoolBucks website to complete the meal distribution forms online. Starting August 31, Roanoke City Public Schools will participate in the USA National School Lunch and School Breakfast program to offer meals to enrolled students during the school year. In order to receive meals, the federal government now requires each household to complete an enrollment form. Here is the link to the MySchoolBucks website:

https://www.myschoolbucks.com/ver2/getmain.action

You can also download and print the form from home. Please return completed forms to your child's school by August 24. Here is a link to download the form:

https://www.rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=580013

post_text: Welcome back teachers! We found plenty of enthusiasm at Virginia Heights Elementary, especially about the school's upgrades. Over the summer, Ms. Burgess decorated the stairway with words of wisdom. She is celebrating her 5th year of teaching. Ms. Gunter joined her for this picture since it is her 28th year of teaching! Teachers told us they are excited and anxious about the year but said "we will figure it out." THANK YOU for everything you do to support children. YOU ARE OUR HEROES!

DRUM ROLL PLEASE.....Molly Murdoch of James Madison Middle is the Grand Prize Winner in our Virtual Summer Reading Program. Thanks to Cox, Molly received a $500 Amazon gift card. She plans to buy additional books from the Percy Jackson series. Congratulations! Pictured with Molly are Superintendent White and Jeff Merritt with Cox Communications.

Thanks to Cox Communications and Central Council PTA for sponsoring this wonderful program. All the winners have been contacted. 20 middle school students have won iPads. We will arrange pick-up once they arrive (hopefully by the end of the week).

post_text: As kids and families prepare for back to school, Dr. Kimberly Dunsmore, chair of Carilion Children's, shares helpful tips to make sure they're ready. These tips are helpful whether students are participating in virtual learning for the first nine weeks, or in-person later in the school year. For more #COVID19 resources and tips, visit: bit.ly/3b5QKDl.

post_text:
If your child needs school supplies, our Back to School Extravaganza will take place Saturday, August 29 at William Fleming High School from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. It will be a Drive-Thru event this year. You only have to leave your vehicle if you need Immunizations. The Health Department will provide Immunizations from 9 a.m. to noon only. Please bring your insurance card and your child's immunization record.

Roanoke City Public Schools will provide transportation at 8:45 a.m. from the following locations: Blue Stone Park, Hunt Manor, Indian Rock Village, Jamestown Place, Landsdowne Park, Melorse Towers, Pilot Street (Country Cookin). The bus leaves promptly at 8:45 a.m. Please wear face coverings on the bus. Durham will provide at least two buses at each location to assist with social distancing.

post_text:
The first student day is Monday, August 31, 2020. Please visit our Back-to-School Center for important dates, school supply lists, Immunization information, and details about our Back-to-School Extravaganza. Here is the link:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/back-to-_school_2020

Teachers may adjust school supply lists when they return this week. Students will most likely need the supplies whether in-person or virtually. Since school supplies are typically cheaper this time of year, we suggest buying now. Use your best judgement.

Many of you have asked about laptop distribution. Schools will be contacting parents/guardians with that information since each one is handling pick-up times differently.

post_text: Help us welcome 125 new teachers to Roanoke City Public Schools! New Teacher Orientation looked much different this year. Due to the pandemic, teachers met in small groups at their school or virtually. While we weren't altogether in one place, they still felt the love. Principals treated new teachers to lunch and gave out special gifts. A group from Fallon Park Elementary even visited the Mill Mountain Star. Welcome to Roanoke. You will do great things!

post_text: WATCH THIS: Principal Mitchem gives us a tour of Phase 3 of the new Fallon Park Elementary. Enjoy this video. The facility is gorgeous!
text: WATCH THIS: Principal Mitchem gives us a tour of Phase 3 of the new Fallon Park Elementary. Enjoy this video. The facility is gorgeous!

post_text: HIP HIP HOORAY! After more than three years of construction, the new Fallon Park Elementary is almost completed. Workers are putting the finishing touches on Phase 3, which includes a renovated gym, a new art and music room, a bus loop, and two new playgrounds! We included a few pictures from Phase 1 & 2. Check back at 6 p.m. tonight when Principal Mitchem takes on a video tour of Phase 3.
text: HIP HIP HOORAY! After more than three years of construction, the new Fallon Park Elementary is almost completed. Workers are putting the finishing touches on Phase 3, which includes a renovated gym, a new art and music room, a bus loop, and two new playgrounds! We included a few pictures from Phase 1 & 2. Check back at 6 p.m. tonight when Principal Mitchem takes on a video tour of Phase 3.

PLEASE READ: The Roanoke City School Board has amended the 2020-2021 School Year Calendar. The Board approved an amendment to the 2020-21 School Calendar reflecting Friday, January 22, 2021, rather than January 15, as a two-hour early dismissal day in order to balance the marking periods. The first student day is Monday, August 31, 2020. Most students will participate in virtual learning for the first nine weeks. Here's a link to the full 2020-2021 School Calendar:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/school_year_calendars

Our students need your vote! During the school year, students from Fishburn Park, Garden City, and Morningside Elementary Schools created ceiling tiles to cheer up patients at Carilion's Children's Hospital. Before being installed, their artwork is on display until August 30 at the Taubman Museum of Art in downtown Roanoke. You can vote for your favorite ceiling title here:

https://www.taubmanmuseum.org/carilion-clinic-healing-ceiling-tiles

You can vote once a day from now until August 23. The winners will receive various art supplies. THANK YOU for voting. Let's hear it for our talented students.

post_text:
PLEASE READ: Back to school is the perfect time to make sure you children are up to date with their vaccines. All students (in person or virtual) are required to have their immunizations. State laws require that children receive a comprehensive physical examination and be adequately immunized appropriate to the child's age before entering public kindergarten or elementary school. All rising 7th graders must receive a Tdap immunization.

The Roanoke City Health Department is hosting a Drive-Thru Immunization Event this Saturday (8/15) from 9 a.m. to noon at 1502 Williamson Road, 2nd floor, Roanoke, VA 24012. Please bring a copy of your child's immunization record. If you have questions about this event, please call (540) 853-5050.

PLEASE SHARE: Welcome to Virginia's Tax-Free Weekend! Due to COVID-19, Roanoke City Public Schools is unable to hold the traditional Load the Bus Campaign. But the need is greater than ever. There are a number of ways you can help students, by donating in-person or virtually. Here are the details:

You can donate at the Walmart stores at Valley View, Bonsack, and Clearbrook. Just look for the bins or donate at the register.

You can drop off school supplies on the City Market in downtown Roanoke until 4 p.m. today. Just look for the school bus. Thank you Alcova Mortgage.

You can also order supplies online. They will be shipped directly to Roanoke City Public Schools. Here are the links to Walmart and Amazon:

https://www.amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/1HCSDJHUEPNKA?ref_=wl_share

PLEASE SHARE: Roanoke City Public Schools is hosting a Virtual Interview Event for Special Education (SPED) Instructional Assistants. They assist classroom teachers by working with individual students or in small groups. The Virtual Interview Event will take place Wednesday, August 12, 2020. You will receive the Zoom information after you apply. Please complete your application by Monday (8/10). Here is the link to apply:

https://rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=12097163

Complete a classified application and apply to the SPED Instructional Assistant Interview Event. For assistance, please call 853-1557.

VIRTUAL SUMMER READING PROGRAM UPDATE: The forms have been submitted! Lisa Kornegay will begin drawing the prizes Wednesday. Roanoke City Public Schools will be awarding close to 70 gift cards, 68 Kindle Fires at the elementary level, and 20 iPads at the middle school level. We will call you if your child wins a prize.

A huge thank you to Cox Communications and Central Council PTA for sponsoring our Virtual Summer Reading Program. Thanks to their support, we are awarding more than $11,000 in prizes. While the program is completed, we encourage your children to keep reading!

REMINDER: Roanoke City Public Schools is holding mobile enrollment events this week for new students. Here are the details:

Wednesday, August 5- William Fleming High School 10 a.m. - 12 noon

Friday, August 7- Fairview Elementary School 10 a.m. - 12 noon

To complete enrollment, please bring proof of residence and the original copy of your child's birth certificate. Interpreters will be available. Your child will receive:

Immunizations on-site (if needed)
Completed enrollment, if necessary documents are presented.

If you have any questions about the requirements, please call (540) 853-2090

FINAL REMINDER: Tomorrow (8/3) is the deadline to submit the final reading logs for the Virtual Summer Reading Programs. You return the forms to your child's school or email them to: read@rcps.info. PLEASE put your phone number on the form. We need a way to contact you if your child's win.

In the second round, prizes include more than 60 gift cards, 68 Kindle Fires for elementary students, and 20 iPads for middle school students. The Grand Prize is a $500 Amazon gift card. THANK YOU to everyone who participated in the Virtual Summer Reading Program. A huge shout out to Cox Communications and Central Council PTA for sponsoring the program. Thanks to their support, we are awarding more than $11,000 in prizes!!!

post_text:
Back to school is the perfect time to make sure your children are up-to-date with their vaccines. Just a reminder, rising 7th graders must receive a Tdap immunization. There are many community resources to receive free immunizations and physicals. Here are the details:

Roanoke City Health Department. Please call the Health Department at (540) 283-5050 to make an appointment. 1502 Williamson Road, 2nd floor, Roanoke, VA 24012

Clinics by appointment only:

Mondays: 8/3, 8/10, 8/17, 8/24

Fridays: 7/31, 8/7, 8/14

Drive through clinic:

Saturday 8/15 from 9 am-12 pm

Bradley Free Clinic – (540) 344-5156

1240 Third Street SW, Roanoke, VA 24016

Clinics by appointment only for children without insurance or are on Medicaid:

Tuesday 8/11 from 4 - 7 pm

Walk-in clinics:

Saturday 8/15 from 10 am - 2 pm

Offers physicals!

New Horizons Healthcare (540) 362-0360

3716 Melrose Ave NW Roanoke, VA 24017

Walk-in clinics:

Thursdays

Offers physicals

post_text: Say it ain't so! Principal Wright of Lincoln Terrace Elementary has accepted a position with Montgomery County Public Schools. Ms. Wright will be the District's Administrator for Equity Compliance. She says this was a difficult decision, especially since she has been with RCPS for 21 years. While this is a sad for all of us who love and admire Principal Wright, we are certainly happy for her promotion. Congratulations. Be sure to offer your best wishes in the comment section.

post_text: Today, architects from Hughes Associates Architects & Engineers toured Preston Park Elementary and reviewed drawings. In fact, Roanoke City Public Schools has architects from five area firms visiting each of our schools. They are evaluating the layouts of classrooms (based on 3ft and 6ft distancing) and hallways for congestion. For example, hallways and stairways may become one way in some of our schools.
text: Today, architects from Hughes Associates Architects & Engineers toured Preston Park Elementary and reviewed drawings. In fact, Roanoke City Public Schools has architects from five area firms visiting each of our schools. They are evaluating the layouts of classrooms (based on 3ft and 6ft distancing) and hallways for congestion. For example, hallways and stairways may become one way in some of our schools.

post_text:
ATHLETICS UPDATE: The VHSL Executive Committee voted this morning to move forward with Model 3 in its re-opening of sports and activities for the 2020-2021 School Year. Model 3 delays all VHSL sports and activities until December 14 and adopts the Condensed Interscholastic Plan. Here are further details:

Season 1 (Winter) December 14 - February 20- basketball, gymnastics, indoor track, swim/dive, wrestling

Season 2 (Fall) February 15 - May 1- cheer, cross country, field hockey, football, golf, volleyball

Season 3 (Spring) April 12 - June 26- baseball, lacrosse, soccer, softball, tennis, track and field
text:
ATHLETICS UPDATE: The VHSL Executive Committee voted this morning to move forward with Model 3 in its re-opening of sports and activities for the 2020-2021 School Year. Model 3 delays all VHSL sports and activities until December 14 and adopts the Condensed Interscholastic Plan. Here are further details:

Season 1 (Winter) December 14 - February 20- basketball, gymnastics, indoor track, swim/dive, wrestling

Season 2 (Fall) February 15 - May 1- cheer, cross country, field hockey, football, golf, volleyball

Season 3 (Spring) April 12 - June 26- baseball, lacrosse, soccer, softball, tennis, track and field

We hope you find this video helpful.

PLEASE READ AND SHARE: Last Tuesday, the Transition and Restoration Task Force presented a Re-Opening Schools Plan to the School Board for its consideration. The proposed plan gives parents choices. Students can participate 100% virtually or in-person four days a week.

Roanoke City Public Schools now needs parents and guardians to confirm plans for each student. The Return to Schools Intent Form is available here: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=RCi4CQkh80yD_BW9Raoixkorc_5DDEZJmFxuwbzonYNUNTJaWlRKOFpJT0w5SllUTDRBVjcxQ0tVOC4u

Please complete the form by Tuesday, July 28. Intent forms will be available in Spanish beginning tomorrow (7/21). Paper copies are available at each school. If you experience an issue, technical support is available from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Please call 853-1000.

Again, we want to thank your feedback. To that end, we have put together answers to some of your commonly asked questions. Here is a link:

https://rcps.info/news/what_s_new/re-opening_schools

post_text:
Band camps are underway this week at Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools. Marching Band certainly looks different this year. Due to COVID-19, there are many precautions, including:

Temperature checks at the beginning of each practice.

Students bring their own water bottles

Most practices are held outside and social distancing is required

If inside, students have to wear a mask if they are less than six feet away from one another

Personal belongings are stored six feet apart

Students have to take their instruments homes

Equipment that has to remain at school is sanitized after each practice, including music stands

Mr. Schmitt and Mr. Sanchez are proud of their students for their cooperation. On the practice field at Patrick Henry, it says "Not today Covid, not today." Well said!

Thanks Ms. McCauley for sending these pictures from the dedication ceremony.

post_text: Virtual Summer Reading Program Kick Off.
text: Virtual Summer Reading Program Kick Off.

post_text:
HAPPENING TODAY: Join Superintendent White for the kick-off to our Virtual Summer Reading Program. It takes place at noon in the bus loop at Round Hill Elementary. Thanks to Cox Communications and Central Council PTA, Roanoke City Schools will award $11,000 in prizes for elementary and middle school students who participate in the Reading Program. Your child must be enrolled in Roanoke City Schools. The prizes include iPads, Kindle Fires, and gift cards. There will be at least four winners from each elementary and middle school.

You don't have to attend the Kick-Off to participate. At the event, we will pass out printed forms and free books to students. Forms are also available at the schools. You can print the forms at home:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/summer_virtual_reading_program

post_text:
WEEKLY UPDATE: The Transition and Restoration Task Force met today and will meet again Friday. Just this week, we received additional guidance from the Department of Education about re-opening schools. The Task Force plans to update the School Board next week. The Board is then expected to vote on a plan the last week of July.

We want to thank the more than 7,000 parents who completed the survey about the re-opening of schools. Our staff has until Thursday night (7/9) to complete its own survey. Please check your email for the survey. Students, parents, staff, and community members can continue to provide written feedback. Here's the link:

https://www.rcps.info/information_center/community_feedback

post_text:
Roanoke City Public Schools is hosting a Black Fathers Festival in partnership with Black Father Family and Fathers Achieving Mindfulness. The event takes place Saturday, July 25 at William Fleming High School. The afternoon will feature food, games, entertainment and resources for families. The event will enrich and empower Black families and the Black community by celebrating Black fatherhood. Masks are strongly encouraged.

Pre-registration is required. Here is the link:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/black-father-festival-tickets-112160579312?utm-medium=discovery&utm-campaign=social&utm-content=attendeeshare&utm-source=strongmail&utm-term=listing

text: Phase 3 of the new Fallon Park Elementary looks fantastic. It includes a renovated gym, a new Fine Arts wing and bus loop, as well as connecting Phase 1 & 2. It will be completed this summer. Enjoy these pictures.

post_text:
Summers are always busy for our maintenance and construction crews. This year is no different. Here is a rundown of this summer's projects:

The following schools are getting new playgrounds: Fishburn Park Elementary, Grandin Court Elementary, Preston Park Elementary, and Virginia Heights Elementary.

Paving is taking place at Grandin Court Elementary, Fairview Elementary, and Noel Taylor Learning Academy.

The roof is being replaced at James Breckinridge Middle, Garden City Elementary, and Grandin Court Elementary.

The following schools are getting new security vestibule near the front entrance: Crystal Spring Elementary, Grandin Court Elementary, Highland Park Elementary, James Breckinridge Middle, Preston Park Elementary, and Virginia Heights Elementary.

Lucy Addison Middle School is getting new bleachers

The HVAC systems are being upgraded for the gyms at Lucy Addison and James Breckinridge Middle Schools

post_text:
PLEASE READ AND SHARE: Like you, Roanoke City Public Schools (RCPS) was disappointed RCPS+ was canceled because of COVID-19. Our summer enrichment program is a huge benefit to elementary and middle school students. That's why we are excited to announce a Virtual Summer Reading Program.

Thanks to Cox Communications and Central Council PTA, RCPS is offering more than $11,000 in prizes for our elementary and middle school students who participate in the Virtual Summer Reading Program. The prizes include gift cards, iPads, and Kindle Fires.

RCPS is holding a kick-off event Wednesday, July 8, 2020 at noon in the bus loop at Round Hill Elementary. Cox Communications will distribute free books to students. Parents/guardians and students are welcome to attend. After the event, we will post the details and the forms on our website and social media channels. Hope to see you July 8th!

Using chalk, they wrote messages of kindness and words of wisdom all across the city, including many of our schools. Dr. Delp, Ms. Huff, and Ms. Reese sent these pictures from Lucy Addison Middle, John P. Fishwick Middle, and Westside Elementary. THANK YOU to everyone who participated. #RoanokeRocks

post_text:
GREAT NEWS: The State Board of Education has recognized Roanoke City Public Schools (RCPS) with the 2020 Board of Education Innovative Practice Award for its summer enrichment program RCPS+. This is the first year the Board has issued the award, which recognizes innovations implemented over the course of two academic years that improve student outcomes. RCPS was one of six school divisions in the Commonwealth of Virginia to receive this prestigious award.

Crystal Spring Elementary received the 2020 Board of Education Highest Achievement Award

The following schools were honored with the 2020 Board of Education Continuous Improvement Award: Fallon Park Elementary, Fishburn Park Elementary, Monterey Elementary, Morningside Elementary, Patrick Henry High School, Preston Park Elementary, Virginia Heights Elementary, Wasena Elementary, and William Fleming High School.

Here's a link with more details about each award:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/2020_exemplar_performance_school_awards

post_text:
After 26 years with Roanoke City Public Schools, Elizabeth Williams is retiring. She was a Special Education teacher before holding various roles at Central Administration. For the last 13 years, Ms. Williams has been the director of Noel Taylor Learning Academy.

Beginning July 1st, Corey Fobare will be the new director of Noel Taylor Learning Academy. Corey grew up in the Roanoke Valley and held various positions in Roanoke County and Henry County Public Schools.

Please help us welcome Mr. Fobare to Roanoke City Schools. We will certainly miss Ms. Williams and wish her all the best with retirement!

Please help us welcome Mr. Fobare to Roanoke City Schools. We will certainly miss Ms. Williams and wish her all the best with retirement!

post_text: During the City of Roanoke School Board Trustee Investiture Ceremony, Verletta White took the oath office. Mrs. White will become superintendent July 1st. At the same ceremony. Dr. Eli Jamison was sworn-in for a second term on the Roanoke City School Board and Natasha Saunders took the Oath of Office for her first term. Ms. Saunders is a Roanoke native and proud graduate of William Fleming High School. Congratulations!

post_text:
THANK YOU to everyone who supported the STAR Council and the Help the Homeless Fund this year. The STAR Council is made up of students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools whose mission is to help our homeless students.

During the pandemic, Roanoke City Public Schools has continued to support our homeless families. Thanks to your donations, we have recently paid for hotel rooms, as well as purchased clothing, hygiene items, and medication.

Additionally, the Help the Homeless Fund is helping to prevent families from becoming homeless. To date, the school system has spent $38,082 helping 254 homeless families (578 students). The fund pays for things like an utility bill or rent to prevent evictions. The funding is being used to fill the gaps after all other community resources have been exhausted.

With 553 students identified as homeless this school year, the STAR Council will continue to raise money and awareness. If you want to help, please check our Help the Homeless webpage:

https://www.rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=2014934

post_text:
MAJOR MILESTONE: Six years ago, students from all five of our middle schools joined the GEAR UP Program. The goal of the federal grant is to increase the number of students going to college, especially first generation college students. Over the six years, GEAR UP students visited colleges and universities, participated in workshops, received tutoring, and much more!

555 GEAR UP students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools are graduating this week. Each GEAR UP student going off to college is receiving a $5,000 scholarship, including Cartlie Vincent (pictured) of William Fleming High School. Cartlie's journey to the University of Virginia will be featured in The Roanoke Times this week.

Congratulations to all the GEAR UP students. Based on federal guidelines, school districts can only have one GEAR UP cohort at one time and must wait a year before reapplying for the grant.

CLASS OF 2020: Roanoke City Public Schools looks forward to honoring our graduating seniors this week. The Virtual Graduation Ceremonies were filmed at the Jefferson Center. A heartfelt thank you to Cyrus Pace for providing the space at no cost.

The ceremonies will air on the District's Facebook page. We also plan to upload them to YouTube. Once uploaded, you will find the YouTube link in the Class of 2020 webpage on our main website. Here is this week's schedule:

Tuesday (6/2)- Forest Park Academy's Ceremony will stream at 6 p.m.

Thursday (6/4)- Patrick Henry High School's Ceremony will air at 10 a.m., followed by William Fleming High School's Ceremony at 2 p.m.

Both Patrick Henry and William Fleming have communicated an opportunity for graduating seniors to walk across the stage to receive their diploma during separate ceremonies this week. Because of COVID-19, everyone must practice social distancing and wear a mask or face covering. To see the letters mailed to seniors, please click on this website:

https://www.rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=13266506

What will Roanoke look like in 20 years? We now have a better idea thanks to some talented students from William Fleming High School. They participated in the Roanoke City Plan 2040 Art Contest. The students captured their vision for the future of Roanoke. The following students took top honors for their photography:

1st Place: Caleb Anders "Caleb Anders City Plan 2020"
2nd Place: Autumn Thompson "Colors of Roanoke", "Mobile Stars", and "Small Things"
3rd Place: Cheyenne Dillion "Roanoke Dam"

Each student will receive a $50 gift card. Students from Patrick Henry High School also participated in the contest. The winners from PH were announced earlier this school year. Congratulations Patriots and Colonels.

post_text:
While searching our digital archives, we found this gem from May, 1976 when the original Fallon Park Elementary was dedicated! The school opened in August, 1975 at a cost of $2.1 million. The dedication ceremony included performances by the William Fleming High School Band, the Patrick Henry High School Strings, and the Fallon Park Elementary School Choir. Mayor Noel C. Taylor and John P. Fishwick delivered remarks. The school is named after Frank J. Fallon since he donated the land for the school.

More than 40 years later, Phase 1 & 2 of the new Fallon Park Elementary are complete. At 3 p.m. today, we will show you the progress of Phase 3.

Taylor and John P. Fishwick delivered remarks. The school is named after Frank J. Fallon since he donated the land for the school.

More than 40 years later, Phase 1 & 2 of the new Fallon Park Elementary are complete. At 3 p.m. today, we will show you the progress of Phase 3.

post_text:
PLEASE READ: Roanoke City Public Schools is planning to deliver food by bus Friday. As you know, the City of Roanoke has seen a significant amount of rain that has led to flooding and street closures. As a result, there could be delays tomorrow, and in some cases, roads will be impassable for our buses. For a list of current road closures, please check out the City of Roanoke's website:

https://roanokeva.gov/1884/Flood-Preparedness

Just a reminder, there is grab and go service from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. at Round Hill and Fallon Park Elementary Schools, and from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at Patrick Henry and William Fleming High School.

As we announced Wednesday, there will be no food service this Monday, on Memorial Day. We appreciate your patience and stay safe.

Just a reminder, there is grab and go service from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. at Round Hill and Fallon Park Elementary Schools, and from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at Patrick Henry and William Fleming High School.

Every year, Roanoke City Public Schools showcases its graduating seniors on our social media channels. We share awards, scholarships, and their future plans. Email us a photo of your senior to seniors@rcps.info. Please include name, school, and information you want to share!

post_text:
#RoanokeRocks Because of COVID-19, ROTEC - Roanoke Technical Education Center had to cancel its annual Extravaganza. But, it didn't stop the CTE Foundation from awarding $7,000 worth of scholarships to ROTEC students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools. Here are this year's recipients:

Estephanie Cole of Patrick Henry High School received a $2,000 scholarship to study Elementary Education at Radford University.

Jania Hutchinson of William Fleming received a $2,000 scholarship to pursue a Education/School Counseling degree at Radford University.

Nirajan Kidariya of Patrick Henry High School will study Computer Science at Virginia Tech with a $1,500 scholarship.

Joseph Valentine of William Fleming is the recipient of a $1,500 scholarship to pursue an Engineering degree at Virginia Tech.

Congratulations Class of 2020!

#RoanokeRocks This truly touched our hearts. A woman donated her entire stimulus check ($1,200) to the Help the Homeless Fund. While she wishes to remain anonymous, we think she deserves a huge pat on the back, even a hug or two!

Roanoke City Schools have identified 545 students as homeless this school year. If you want to help, check out our Help the Homeless website:

https://www.rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=2014934

During the Teacher of the Year Banquet each year, Roanoke City Public Schools showcases the three finalists through video. Since the banquet was canceled this year, we are highlighting the finalists on social media. Tuesday, it was Ms. Janney of ROTEC. Wednesday, we featured Ms. Shamy of Roanoke Academy. Today, it is Ms. Wasson, this year's Teacher of the Year. . WATCH THIS VIDEO to learn more about this amazing teacher from Fallon Park Elementary.

Thank you to Roanoke Valley Television RVTV-3 for shooting and editing all three videos.

In an effort to help parents during this difficult time, Decca Knight, Licensed Professional Counselor and Parenting Educator, has created a series of parenting videos on the School Counseling and Equity Department’s YouTube Channel. This video helps parents identify their parenting triggers and learn how to cope with them.

Here's a link to the YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbkcx95mgQyUbCZ0CJErvRg?view_as=subscriber

post_text:
WATCH THIS: Ms. Hackworth of Woodrow Wilson Middle School has a really cool Science project you can do at home. You can even call yourself a magician. You will need the following materials:

A container (preferably metal or glass). Plastic will work as long as you do not leave it in too long
Acetone(finger nail polish remover). For a more dramatic effect, Walmart or Lowes sell inexpensive acetone
Styrofoam and or legos. (If you do not have styrofoam you can use old cd cases, plastic yogurt containers, disposable razors.

CLASS OF 2020: Reid Mitchell of Patrick Henry High School plans to attend the University of Virginia (UVA). While at PH, Reid was a member of the wrestling team, qualifying in States, as well as a National Honor Society Group Leader. He earned his Eagle Scout Award, founded PHed Talks and PH Data and was a co-founder of RT Online Marketing, LLC.

Our Career and Technical Education Programs are some of the best in the country. Students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools can pursue more than a dozen career paths at ROTEC - Roanoke Technical Education Center. Since schools are closed for the remainder of the school year, ROTEC teachers are holding a virtual Open House. Every Tuesday and Thursday this month, they are showcasing the different programs at ROTEC. WATCH THIS VIDEO for a message from Principal Duncan.

post_text:
CLASS OF 2020: Jostens has scheduled a Drive-Thru Graduation & Class Ring delivery event for Thursday, May 7 at Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools. Jostens will distribute caps and gowns, as well as class rings. Here are the details:

Patrick Henry: (A-L) 11:00 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.; (M-Z) 1:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m.
Please drive to the bus loop near the auditorium. Do not leave your car. You simply pull up and provide your name.

William Fleming: (A-L) 11:00 a.m. to 1:30 p.m.; (M-Z) 1:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. Please pull up in front of the Auditorium curbside. Do not leave your car. You simply pull up and provide your name.

*If possible, please make sure your order is paid in full prior to pick up. If you have a balance, please pay online at orders.jostens.com or call 1-800-jostens between 8:30AM-5:00PM or locally at 540-387-4269 between 11AM-5PM

*CASH ACCEPTED IN ENVELOPE WITH CORRECT CHANGE, NO CHECKS WILL BE ACCEPTED

*Once you receive your graduation items you may contact Jostens at 1-800-JOSTENS or locally at 540-387-4269 with any questions.

post_text:
Cox Communications is extending free internet for students and their families until July 15, 2020. If you recently signed up for Connect2Compete, your free service will automatically be extended to July 15.

After July 15, 2020, families may cancel without penalty or pay $9.95 a month thereafter. This offer is available to new customers. Cox is waiving installation fees. You will be provided with instructions on how to connect to your new in-home internet services. Resources for technical assistance are also available (at no charge). Here is a link to sign-up:

https://www.cox.com/residential/internet/connect2compete.html?sc_id=cr_dm_camp_z_c2c_vanity

Then scroll down and then click on the link that says Getting Started.

If you have questions, please call 855-222-3252.

post_text:
During these challenging times, many of us are struggling with parenting our children. Decca Knight, a licensed professional counselor and parenting educator, helps us identify our parenting style and work towards an approach that is best for our kids.

The School Counseling and Equity Department has established a YouTube channel. For more helpful videos, check out the page:

Despite the closure of schools, we can still celebrate Teacher Appreciation Week (May 4-8). We are asking students to make cards, write letters, or create artwork for your teacher(s). Email completed works to art@rcps.info. Please include your child's name & school. During Teacher Appreciation Week, we highlight your gratitude on the District's social media channels.

post_text:
Since we are unable to go to the movies, we have a fun math lesson for middle school students that incorporates popcorn! Help Buddy figure out which container will hold the most popcorn. Is it Container A or B? Use the formula for the volume of a rectangular prism to determine the volume of each container and then compare your answers. Here is the formula:

V= length X width X height

WATCH THIS VIDEO and then post your answers in the comment section. We will reveal the answer later today. Thanks Ms. Barker and Ms. Trongdon for your help with this video.

Is it Container A or B? Use the formula for the volume of a rectangular prism to determine the volume of each container and then compare your answers. Here is the formula:

V= length X width X height

WATCH THIS VIDEO and then post your answers in the comment section. We will reveal the answer later today. Thanks Ms. Barker and Ms. Trongdon for your help with this video.

post_text:
SPANISH TRANSLATION:

Entregaremos comida usando las rutas consolidadas de autobuses el martes, miércoles y viernes de esta semana. Ahora hay cuatro rutas de entrega de comidas. Si aún no lo ha hecho, revise cada una en nuestro sitio web y encuentre la ruta más cercana a su hogar. Puede llamar al 853-1000 en los días de entrega si necesita ayuda adicional.

También tendremos servicio de comida para llevar el martes, miércoles y viernes de 10 a 11 a.m. en las escuelas primarias Fallon Park y Round Hill, así como de 11:30 a.m. a 12:30 p.m. en las escuelas secundarias Patrick Henry y William Fleming. Esta información se publica en nuestro sitio web y en los canales de redes sociales.

Cox Communications ha simplificado el proceso de solicitud para registrarse en Internet gratis. Para hacerlo más fácil, utilice el enlace publicado en nuestro sitio web. Es compatible con dispositivos móviles. Si no puede solicitar en línea, aparece un número de teléfono. Recuerde que esta oferta solo está disponible para nuevos clientes.

https://rcps.info/news/what_s_new/free_internet_for_students

MEAL DELIVERY UPDATE:

We have consolidated bus routes to minimize the amount of staff needed. We will deliver food by bus this Wednesday (4/8) and Friday (4/10). Each student will receive two days of meals. Here is a link to the new routes:

https://rcps.info/news/what_s_new/coronavirus_information

Please review each route and use the one closest to your home. Additionally, we will have grab and go service Wednesday and Friday from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools.

If you have any questions, call our Hotline Wednesday and Friday at 853-1000 between 9:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. Thank you for your cooperation as we help feed our students as well as maintain the safety of staff.

post_text:
CLASS OF 2020: Seniors who have passed 1st semester and 3rd nine weeks, have completed required coursework for the year. There are exceptions if you are in AP, Dual Enrollment, or taking a class through Virtual Virginia. All seniors, including anyone who feels they have completed requirements need to confirm with their counselor where they stand in regards to graduation. Contact information for each counselor is available in this link:

https://www.rcps.info/news/what_s_new/class_of_2020_information

All students in grades 9-12 will receive a pass/fail grade for the 4th nine weeks and second semester unless they notify their teachers directly that they would prefer a letter grade. Deadline to make this request is April 17, 2020 for seniors and May 29, 2020 for underclassmen. All requests must be made by the parent via email.

Contact information for each counselor is available in this link:

All students in grades 9-12 will receive a pass/fail grade for the 4th nine weeks and second semester unless they notify their teachers directly that they would prefer a letter grade. Deadline to make this request is April 17, 2020 for seniors and May 29, 2020 for underclassmen. All requests must be made by the parent via email.

post_text: PLEASE READ: We understand there is a letter circulating on social media claiming all high school juniors in Roanoke City Schools are required to attend summer school. THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO TRUTH TO THIS. The letter is a hoax. Please stop circulating the letter. We realize it is April Fool’s Day. Typically, we appreciate a good joke. However, this is not the time for this. In the future, if you see something on social media that concerns you, please reach out to your principal or send us a message on our Facebook page.

SPANISH TRANSLATION:

Pedimos disculpas por cualquier inconveniente y dificultad que la suspensión de la entrega de alimentos les haya causado a usted y a sus hijos. El Distrito planea continuar alimentando a los estudiantes mientras mantenemos la seguridad de nuestro personal. En preparación para las vacaciones de primavera, tendremos un servicio para llevar el viernes en los siguientes sitios de 11 am a 1 pm: Fallon Park Elementary, Round Hill Elementary, Roanoke Academy for Mathematics and Science, Patrick Henry High School y William Fleming High School .

El Distrito está desarrollando un nuevo modelo para continuar la entrega de alimentos utilizando rutas consolidadas de autobuses. Recibirá una llamada automática el domingo por la noche y el plan se publicará en nuestro sitio web y canales de redes sociales.

3/31/20 UPDATE: Roanoke City Public Schools apologizes for any inconvenience and hardship the suspension of food delivery caused you and your children.

The District plans to continue feeding students while maintaining the safety of our staff.

In preparation for Spring Break, we will have grab and go service Friday (4/3) at the following sites from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m.: Fallon Park Elementary, Round Hill Elementary, Roanoke Academy for Mathematics and Science, Patrick Henry High School, and William Fleming High School.

The District is developing a new model to resume the delivery of food using consolidated bus routes. You will receive a robo call Sunday (4/5) evening and the plan will be posted on our website and social media channels

post_text:
SPANISH TRANSLATION:

Estoy llamando sobre los servicios de comida. Hasta un nuevo aviso, tenemos que suspender la entrega de alimentos en autobús.

Sin embargo, el Distrito Escolar proporcionará un servicio para llevar mañana, martes, de 11 a.m. a 1 p.m. en las escuelas Fallon Park Elementary, Round Hill Elementary, Patrick Henry High School y William Fleming High School.
La Junta Escolar se reunirá mañana por la tarde para discutir la directiva sobre la permanencia en el hogar del Gobernador, y proporcionaremos una actualización sobre el servicio de alimentos después de la reunión.

Si no puede visitar ninguno de estos sitios y necesita alimentos, el Gobernador le pide que llame al 2-1-1.
El soporte técnico remoto en ambas escuelas secundarias también ha sido suspendido.

Además, todos los edificios escolares ahora están cerrados y los empleados no deben presentarse a trabajar hasta nuevo aviso.

Apreciamos el trabajo duro de todos para entregar comida a nuestros estudiantes. Estamos buscando soluciones y lo mantendremos informado.

post_text:
PLEASE READ: Until further notice, we have to suspend food delivery by bus.

However, the School District will provide grab and go service tomorrow (3/31), Tuesday, from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. at Fallon Park Elementary, Round Hill Elementary, Patrick Henry High School, and William Fleming High School.

The School Board is meeting tomorrow afternoon to discuss the Governor’s stay-at-home directive, and we will provide an update on food service after the meeting.

If you cannot visit any of these sites and need food, the Governor asks that you call 2-1-1.

Grab and Go Tech Support at both high schools has also been suspended.

Additionally, all school buildings are now closed and employees are not to report to work until further notice.

We appreciate everyone’s hard-work in delivering food to our students. Today, the District delivered nearly 17,000 meals. We are seeking solutions and will keep you advised.

If you cannot visit any of these sites and need food, the Governor asks that you call 2-1-1.

Grab and Go Tech Support at both high schools has also been suspended.

Additionally, all school buildings are now closed and employees are not to report to work until further notice.

We appreciate everyone’s hard-work in delivering food to our students. Today, the District delivered nearly 17,000 meals. We are seeking solutions and will keep you advised.

#RoanokeRocks This week, Roanoke City Schools delivered nearly 75,000 meals to students. THANK YOU to our staff, as well as SodexoMAGIC and Durham School Services for helping to deliver meals.

These messages greeted our helpers outside Patrick Henry High School this morning.

IMPORTANT REMINDER: Meals will continue to be delivered to students next week. On Tuesday, March 31, order forms will be included with the meals. These forms need to be returned to the bus on Wednesday, April 1. Families who return a form will receive an additional six days of meals on Friday, April 3. This will provide for families over Spring Break.

With schools closed because of Coronavirus, Roanoke City Public Schools realizes this may cause a lot of stress for your children. The School Counseling and Equity Department is here to help!

Our school counselors and social workers are available to provide ongoing services to students and families. You may reach your child's school counselor or school social worker by calling their school. Here are also some useful links:

https://confidentparentsconfidentkids.org/2020/03/13/my-kids-school-is-closed-so-now-what/

https://childmind.org/article/talking-to-kids-about-the-coronavirus/

Many of our schools practice mindfulness with students. In this video, Mr. Richardson of Preston Park Elementary shares some techniques that may be helpful to you and your children.

Quiero comenzar agradeciéndole su paciencia y comprensión durante estas circunstancias sin precedentes.

La entrega de comidas se continuará el lunes. El Distrito ha consolidado 15 rutas de autobuses para proporcionar un servicio más rápido. Esto incluye áreas como nuestros complejos de apartamentos más grandes.

https://rcps.info/news/what_s_new/coronavirus_information

Si no ve su número de autobús en la lista, entonces su ruta es la misma de esta semana. No olvide que la recolección de comida está disponible en ambas escuelas secundarias entre el mediodía y la 1 de la tarde. De lunes a viernes.

Nuevamente, permítanme expresar nuestro más profundo agradecimiento a los miembros de nuestro personal que ayudaron a entregar comidas esta semana. No podríamos haberlo hecho sin el apoyo de SodexoMAGIC y Durham School Services. Durante la semana, entregamos casi 50,000 comidas. Es realmente inspirador ver a todos los que han contribuido.

No anticipamos ninguna llamada automática este fin de semana. Gracias y que tenga una buena noche
text:
UPDATE IN SPANISH:

Quiero comenzar agradeciéndole su paciencia y comprensión durante estas circunstancias sin precedentes.

La entrega de comidas se continuará el lunes. El Distrito ha consolidado 15 rutas de autobuses para proporcionar un servicio más rápido. Esto incluye áreas como nuestros complejos de apartamentos más grandes.

https://rcps.info/news/what_s_new/coronavirus_information

Si no ve su número de autobús en la lista, entonces su ruta es la misma de esta semana. No olvide que la recolección de comida está disponible en ambas escuelas secundarias entre el mediodía y la 1 de la tarde. De lunes a viernes.

Nuevamente, permítanme expresar nuestro más profundo agradecimiento a los miembros de nuestro personal que ayudaron a entregar comidas esta semana. No podríamos haberlo hecho sin el apoyo de SodexoMAGIC y Durham School Services. Durante la semana, entregamos casi 50,000 comidas. Es realmente inspirador ver a todos los que han contribuido.

No anticipamos ninguna llamada automática este fin de semana. Gracias y que tenga una buena noche

post_text:
UPDATE 3/20/20:

THANK YOU you for your patience and understanding during these unprecedented circumstances.

The delivery of meals will resume Monday (3/23/20). Roanoke City Public Schools has consolidated 15 bus routes to provide faster service. This includes areas such as our larger apartment complexes. Here's a link:

https://rcps.info/news/what_s_new/coronavirus_information

If you do not see your bus number listed, then your route is the same as this week. Don’t forget that meal pick up is available at both high schools between noon and 1 p.m. Monday through Friday.

Again, let us express our deepest appreciation to our staff members who helped deliver meals this week. We couldn’t have done it without the support of SodexoMAGIC and Durham School Services. For the week, we delivered almost 50,000 meals. It is truly inspiring to see everyone who has pitched in.

We don’t anticipate any robo calls this weekend. Thank you and have a good night.

PLEASE READ AND SHARE: At 2:30 Friday (3/13/20), Governor Ralph Northam ordered all schools (K-12) in Virginia closed for two weeks because of COVID-19. You will receive additional information about instruction, the delivery of food for students, and other services by noon Monday (3/16/20). This is effective from March 16 through Friday, March 27, 2020. Here is a link to Governor Northam's announcement:

https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2020/march/headline-854442-en.html

Antes del mediodía del lunes 16 de marzo, les enviaremos información adicional acerca de la enseñanza y la distribución de comida para los estudiantes, al igual que acerca de otros servicios. Esta medida aplica del 16 de marzo al viernes 27 de marzo del 2020

post_text: This year's theme is "Mission Accepted." We found a great example at Virginia Heights Elementary. The school has started a Help Save the Next Girl Chapter for 4th and 5th grade girls. The club's goal is to empower women and build self-esteem. Recently, officers from Roanoke Police Department - VA visited the school to educate students about personal safety. The students will march as a chapter in the upcoming St. Patrick's Day parade in downtown Roanoke.

post_text: To celebrate Black History Month, John P. Fishwick Middle School students created art inspired by artist Lois Mailou Jones. Her fondest wish was to be known as an "artist," without labels like "black artist" or "woman artist."

This is Public Schools Week! Today, Roanoke City Public Schools (RCPS) is proud to highlight its amazing Fine Arts Programs:

Thanks to VH1 Save The Music Foundation, our elementary students have access to musical instruments

Our middle and high schools have orchestra, band, and choral programs

The NAMM Foundation named RCPS one of the Best Communities for Music Education for seven consecutive years

Ten music ensembles received Superior ratings at District Music Assessment

Our amazing Fine Arts teachers & talented students are another reason why #RoanokeRocks

post_text: Lucy Addison Middle is hosting the "Wendell Ball Legacy Series" as part of Black History Month. Ms. Harrington says it honors Wendell Ball, a long-time Roanoke City educator who passed away in December. With the help of volunteers from Trifecta, students first painted portraits of Mr. Ball. Throughout the month, various speakers have visited Addison to share advice and their personal stories. Speakers have included Mayor Sherman Lea, Peter Lewis, Dr. Wayne Harris, Anita and Charles Price, Champ Hubbard, Mr. Ball's granddaughter, and so many more!

Bobby Flay would be proud! To celebrate Career and Technical Education (CTE) Month, SodexoMAGIC hosted the first annual Culinary Throwdown. ROTEC - Roanoke Technical Education Center students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming High Schools competed in various categories. They were judged based on time, taste, and presentation.

The Grand Prize winners received a tablet. Each contestant went home with various cooking utensils. THANK YOU to SodexoMAGIC for donating the food and the prizes. It was a great way for these future chefs to get valuable experience. These community partnerships are another reason why #RoanokeRocks

post_text:
It's game-on at William Fleming High School. The Virginia High School League (VHSL) is piloting 35 esports programs across the Commonwealth. Esports is a form of sport competition using video games. 20 students are part of the esports team at William Fleming. They meet every day after school to fine-tune their gaming skills and compete against their classmates.

Mr. Goetz, Fleming's team sponsor, says esports are a great opportunity to reach students who don't always participate in extra-curricular activities. He says students are learning teamwork and are held to same academic standards as athletes.

post_text:
Roanoke City Schools joined forces with the City of Roanoke, emergency personnel, area law enforcement, and Carilion for an Emergency Drill at The Berglund Center. THANK YOU to everyone who participated. We all learned a lot!

The Drill focused on the reunification process. During a true emergency, our goal is to reunite you with your children as quickly as possible. We ask for our family’s assistance in the following three ways if we have an emergency at a school:

Stay Home- we know the natural instinct as a parent/guardian during an emergency is to come to the school. You may endanger yourself and your child.

Stay informed- The District will provide timely information with instructions through robo calls, text messages, our social media channels, and the local news media.

Be ready- we will provide the location to reunite with your children. It will be crucial that you bring a picture ID. District personnel must identify the appropriate parent/guardian before releasing children. We can only release students to individuals listed on the emergency card.

Stay informed- The District will provide timely information with instructions through robo calls, text messages, our social media channels, and the local news media.

Be ready- we will provide the location to reunite with your children. It will be crucial that you bring a picture ID. District personnel must identify the appropriate parent/guardian before releasing children. We can only release students to individuals listed on the emergency card.

post_text: Author Gary Keel is speaking at the Raleigh Court Library this weekend about his book "Executive Order 14900." Today, Keel spoke to 150 students at Patrick Henry High School. He shared his experiences working for the federal government and what it takes to write a political thriller. The author is offering two $1,000 scholarships for City high school students who write an essay about freedom and the constitution. Thank you to Roanoke Public Libraries for providing this opportunity to our students.

post_text:
It is now easier to apply for pre-school. Today at Roanoke Academy, Virginia's Secretary of Education announced a new initiative with the United Way of Roanoke Valley, Smart Beginnings of Greater Roanoke, Total Action for Progress (TAP), and area school systems including Roanoke City Public Schools. Smart2Start is a coordinated enrollment system for all publicly funded pre-school programs in the Roanoke Valley. Think of it as a one stop shop to apply. The enrollment process begins tomorrow (2/1) for the 2020-2021 School Year. You can access this link Saturday:

www.smart2start.org

Additionally, Roanoke City Schools are sending paper applications home with students.

post_text:
SUPERINTENDENT SEARCH UPDATE: McPherson & Jacobson, the firm hired to conduct the superintendent search, will hold a series of stakeholder meetings to gather input to determining the qualities of the next Superintendent for Roanoke City Schools. These meetings will include students, staff, parents/guardians, and members of our community. Parents/Guardians please attend this meeting:

Tuesday, February 11- Consultants will gather input from Parents/Guardians, and PTA members. The meeting is open to anyone who wants to provide feedback. This meeting will take place at 7 p.m. at William Fleming High School Auditorium

Additionally, an online survey will be available from February 7 through February 13. Access to the online survey, which will be in English and Spanish, will be available beginning February 7. We will post the survey link on the District’s website and social media channels.

post_text: Sometimes, students just need a place to chill out. That's the idea behind a new Calming Room at James Breckinridge Middle. It is a quiet space equipped with soothing music, soft lighting, and plenty of activities to help students relax. The goal is to help students de-escalate when upset or having a bad day. Since the Calming Room opened in September, Breckinridge's school counselor says referrals to In-School Suspension (ISS) have dropped significantly.

post_text:
SUPERINTENDENT SEARCH UPDATE: The Roanoke City School Board has hired McPherson & Jacobson to conduct a nationwide search to find the next superintendent for Roanoke City Public Schools. This afternoon, the Board met with the consultants to set expectations, time lines, and establish the criteria for the new superintendent.

The School Board is committed to transparency and public input. In February, the consultants will conduct stakeholder meetings. There will also be an online survey for students, parents/guardians, employees, and community members. Once finalized, we will share the survey on our website (www.rcps.info) as well as our social media channels.

The School Board expects to hire the new superintendent by June.
text:
SUPERINTENDENT SEARCH UPDATE: The Roanoke City School Board has hired McPherson & Jacobson to conduct a nationwide search to find the next superintendent for Roanoke City Public Schools. This afternoon, the Board met with the consultants to set expectations, time lines, and establish the criteria for the new superintendent.

The School Board is committed to transparency and public input. In February, the consultants will conduct stakeholder meetings. There will also be an online survey for students, parents/guardians, employees, and community members. Once finalized, we will share the survey on our website (www.rcps.info) as well as our social media channels.

The School Board expects to hire the new superintendent by June.

HAPPENING TODAY: Roanoke City Public Schools is a trauma-informed school district. We realize parents/guardians play an important role in preventing Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs). The District is hosting two community meetings called "The Trauma-Responsive Parent." The first one is this evening (1/13/20) at 6 p.m. at William Fleming High School. Dinner will be served.

There will be an additional meeting Wednesday, January 22, 2020 at Patrick Henry High School from 6 to 7:30 p.m.

post_text: ROTEC - Roanoke Technical Education Center held an Open House to showcase its new Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA) Program. The classroom was recently renovated with new paint, furniture, and medical supplies. There are currently 13 Patrick Henry and 14 William Fleming students enrolled in the program. It was made possible thanks to support from the Claude Moore Scholars Program and Springtree Health and Rehabilitation. Our Career and Technical Education (CTE) Programs are another reason why #RoanokeRocks

post_text: Please welcome Anna Unversaw to Roanoke City Public Schools. She is the new principal of Lucy Addison Middle School. Ms. Unversaw looks forward to meeting staff, students, and parents/guardians!

post_text: Ms. Desper of Patrick Henry High School set out to prove that Geometry can be fun! During a Lab Day, students used hot wheels tracks to connect with slope, midpoint, circle of equation, distance, and physic problems on speed. Another group built non-convex polygons. Finally, students strapped on virtual reality googles for an out of this world experience. They rode a roller coaster, swam with sharks, and went skydiving! Mission Accomplished Ms. Desper!

Winter Break is almost here! Just a reminder, students will dismiss two hours early Friday (12/20). Pre-school and kindergarten parents, please remember to meet your child’s bus early on Friday.

Staff and students are off for Winter Break from December 23 thru January 3. We return Monday, January 6, 2020!

Solo un recordatorio, los estudiantes saldrán dos horas temprano el viernes, 20 de diciembre.

El personal y los estudiantes estarán libres para las vacaciones de invierno del 23 de diciembre al 3 de enero. ¡Regresamos el lunes 6 de enero del 2020!

Each year, Roanoke City Public Schools (RCPS) publishes an Equity and Balanced Scorecard. It is a report card of sorts for the District. The data shows our accomplishments, as well as areas that need improvement. RCPS is one of the few school systems in the country that produces this type of report. Please read both scorecards. They are chock full of information. Here are the links:

Equity:

https://go.boarddocs.com/vsba/roacps/Board.nsf/files/BJJGSB4509E0/$file/2018-19_equity%20scorecard.pdf

Balanced

https://go.boarddocs.com/vsba/roacps/Board.nsf/files/BHMUAN7A8455/$file/Balanced%20Scorecard.pdf

If you would like a paper copy, please call 853-2816.

post_text: This is going to be a busy, but exciting weekend, at the new Fallon Park Elementary. This evening, crews will move all the boxes into Phase 2. Teachers will then set up their new classrooms throughout the weekend to get ready for Monday's opening. Today, students moved in their personal belongings and toured the second phase for the first time. Enjoy these pictures and the new facility!

post_text:
This year's theme is Mission Accepted. As we return from Thanksgiving Break, we congratulate all of you on the following accomplishments:

All Roanoke City Schools are fully accredited

90% on-time graduation rate

The NAMM Foundation has named RCPS one of the Best Communities for Music Education for seven consecutive years

Grandin Court Elementary was named a 2019 National Blue Ribbon School

William Fleming High School was named a National Unified Champion Banner School by the Special Olympics

What will the rest of the school year bring? We can't wait to find out. Please watch our new Promotional Video to learn more about Roanoke City Public Schools.

post_text: Thank you @RepBenCline for honoring Superintendent Bishop on the House Floor for her decades of service to the children of Roanoke City Public Schools.
shared_text:
Congressman Ben Cline
November 21, 2019 at 12:30 PM ·

Dr. Rita Bishop has served Roanoke City Public Schools well as its superintendent for more than a decade. Yesterday, I honored her commitment to our District’s students on the House Floor and wished her a happy, well-deserved retirement at the end of the school year.

post_text: GREAT NEWS: Jania Hutchinson of William Fleming/ROTEC is the first Teachers for Tomorrow cadet to pass all three portions of the Praxis Core exam! The Praxis Core is a basic skills test which covers mathematics, reading and writing, and is a required examination to teach in most states. Way to go Jania. Thanks Ms. Smith for sharing this wonderful news.

post_text:
It has been a banner year so far for our Fine Arts Programs. Let's congratulate the following bands and orchestra students for these major accomplishments:

The Patrick Henry High School Marching Band received a Superior rating for the second straight year at State Band Assessment. Additionally, the Marching Patriots earned Grand Champions (the highest honor) at the Cavalier Classic Band Competition

The William Fleming High School Marching Band received 1st place in Marching at the Lynchburg Classic and 1st place in Music at the Cavalier Classic

Six students from Patrick Henry and William Fleming earned a spot in the Senior Regional Orchestra. They are as follows:

Cartlie Vincent of William Fleming (Bass)
Lacy Ngo of William Fleming (Violin)
Briana Clark of William Fleming (Violin)
Martha Chen of Patrick Henry (Violin)
Misha Wiley of Patrick Henry (Cello)
Sydney Light of Patrick Henry (Bass)

CONGRATULATIONS!

post_text: The Food Services Committee met for the first time this school year. It is made up of administrators, SodexoMAGIC employees, parents, and students. Keiajah Gordon-McGhee of William Fleming and Isaiah Waldron of Patrick Henry share feedback and offer suggestions. For example, the potato bar is popular with students and they want more of it. SodexoMAGIC has served approximately 33,600 more lunches than this time last year.

post_text:
FALLON PARK ELEMENTARY UPDATE: We are happy to announce Phase 2 of the new Fallon Park Elementary is ahead of schedule. As a result, we now anticipate teachers and students moving in before Winter Break. The second phase includes new administrative offices, a cafeteria, and a two-story wing with 13 additional classrooms.

Phase 3 will begin in January. It will include the demolition of the current school. Crews will also renovate the gym and convert the current cafeteria into a Fine Arts wing. Enjoy these amazing pictures!
text:
FALLON PARK ELEMENTARY UPDATE: We are happy to announce Phase 2 of the new Fallon Park Elementary is ahead of schedule. As a result, we now anticipate teachers and students moving in before Winter Break. The second phase includes new administrative offices, a cafeteria, and a two-story wing with 13 additional classrooms.

Phase 3 will begin in January. It will include the demolition of the current school. Crews will also renovate the gym and convert the current cafeteria into a Fine Arts wing. Enjoy these amazing pictures!

post_text:
HELP THE HOMELESS UPDATE: Roanoke City Public Schools has identified 324 students as homeless so far this school year. Our Help the Homeless Fund is preventing families from becoming homeless. To date, the school system has spent $31,080 helping 211 families (473 students). The fund pays for things like an utility bill or rent to prevent evictions. The funding is being used to fill the gaps after all other community resources have been exhausted.

If you want to help our homeless students, please check out our Help the Homeless website. You can make a donation using our PayPal account. Here's a link:

https://www.rcps.info/cms/One.aspx?portalId=468655&pageId=2014934

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

MARK YOUR CALENDARS: The 4th annual Breakfast with Santa will take place Saturday, December 7, 2019 at William Fleming High School. Proceeds will benefit homeless students in Roanoke City Schools.

We need sponsors to make this fundraiser a success. If your business wants to sponsor this event, please send us a private message here on Facebook or call (540) 853-2816.

Breakfast with Santa is sponsored by the STAR Council (Students Take Action in Roanoke). It is a group of students from Patrick Henry & William Fleming High Schools whose mission is to help our homeless students. THANK YOU!
